raw_text:
Fockers retain film chart crown
 
 Comedy Meet The Fockers has held on to the number one spot at the North American box office for a second week.
 
 It took $42.8m (£23.7m) at the weekend, making its overall takings more than $163m (£90m) in 12 days, according to studio estimates. It took $19.1m (£9.9m) on Christmas Day alone, the highest takings on that day in box office history. The sequel to the Ben Stiller comedy Meet The Parents stars Robert De Niro, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand. The success of Meet the Fockers could help produce record box office revenue for 2004, said Paul Dergarabedian, president of the industry's tracker Exhibitor Relations. "We've had a much stronger than anticipated final week of the year that helped the industry end on a high note," said Mr Dergarabedian.
 
 Meet the Fockers also broke the box office records for the most money taken on New Year's Eve, when it made $12.2m (£6.2m), and New Year's Day, when it took $18m (£9.4m). The previous New Year's Eve record was set in 2000 by Cast Away with $8.5m (£4.5m). The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King had held the New Year's Day title with $12.8m (£6.7m). However, Christmas takings were down 26.5% on 2003's figures - which was blamed on Christmas falling over a weekend this year. This weekend's top 12 films took an estimated $125.4m (£65.8m), a 4.3% increase on the same weekend last year. But there were no major releases last week to provide competition to Meet the Fockers or Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, which finished in second place with $14.7m (£7.7m). The Aviator, starring Leonardo DiCaprio as Howard Hughes, ended up in third position after taking $11.2m (£5.9m). Comedy Fat Albert - co-written by Bill Cosby - moved down the chart to fourth place after taking $10.7m (£5.6m).
llama3.2:1b: Fockers retains box office crown, making $42.8m in 12 days and more than $163m overall in 12 days. It surpassed Meet The Parents in weekend two. Christmas Day saw the highest single-day takings since 2001 with $19.1m. The film broke records for New Year's Eve ($12.2m) and New Year's Day ($18m).
llama3.2:3b: Meet The Fockers has held onto the number one spot at the North American box office for a second week, taking $42.8m and making over $163m in 12 days. It broke box office records on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day. The industry ended the year on a high note, with Christmas takings down 26.5% due to falling over a weekend.
gemma2:2b: Meet the Fockers maintained its top spot at the North American box office for a second week, grossing $42.8 million over the weekend. The film's total revenue has surpassed $163 million in 12 days, and it set records for highest Christmas Day takings and New Year's Eve/New Year's Day earnings. The success of Meet the Fockers is contributing to a positive end to 2004 for the box office industry. Other notable films include "Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events" in second place and "The Aviator," which placed third.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Fockers returns box office hit

Meet The Fockers, a comedy, has won first place in North America's box office charts for the third week in a row. It made $42.8 million in Canada and $19. 1 million in the United States in one weekend, according to box-office estimates. It has broken the record for most money taken on New Year's Eve with $12. 2 million at New Year's Day this year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Meet The Fockers holds on to top spot, topping North American box office with $42.8 million in two weeks and a record-breaking Christmas Day performance of $19.1 million. It broke New Year's Eve and New Year's Day records while marking an 8% decline in December following previous years' high figures.
qwen2.5:3b: Meet The Fockers held the number one spot at the North American box office for a second week, earning over $163 million in 12 days and nearly $42 million ($23.7 million) during the weekend. It broke records for highest takings on Christmas Day and New Year's Eve, including breaking the previous New Year's Eve record with $12.2 million. Despite a 26.5% drop from 2003 in Christmas box office revenue due to Christmas falling over a weekend this year, Meet The Fockers' success helped produce record-breaking revenue for 2004. The film finished second to Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events and third place after The Aviator, while Fat Albert moved down the chart to fourth place.

The sequel to the Ben Stiller comedy Meet The Parents stars Robert De Niro, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand. The success of Meet the Fockers could help produce record box office revenue for 2004, said Paul Dergarabedian, president of the industry's tracker Exhibitor Relations.

"We've had a much stronger than anticipated final week of the year that helped the industry end on a high note," said Mr Dergarabedian.

Fockers retain film chart crown, comedy meets the fockers holds on top spot for second week in a row, takings more than $163 million in 12 days, and it's all thanks to Robert De Niro, Dustin Hoffman, and Barbra Streisand.

Comedy Meet The Fockers retained box office number one in North America for two weeks, generating $42.8 million at the weekend and over $163 million overall. They broke their box office record by taking $19.1 million on Christmas Day alone, setting a new high. Their strong final week boosted 2004 revenue, with Comedy Fat Albert finishing second for $10.7 million and Aviator third for $11.2 million, while "The Lord of the Rings" won New Year's Day but fell short in other categories.

The film grossed $42.8m (-42%) on its second day of release, topping the record set by the Lord of the Rings trilogy in the New Year's Day slot last year. Despite a drop in box office takings due to Christmas falling over a weekend this year, there were no major new releases to challenge Meet the Focker or Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, which finished in second place with $14.7m (-25%) and third place respectively after taking $11.2m (-30%), $10.7m (-26%). The Aviator, starring Leonardo DiCaprio as Howard Hughes, ended up in fourth position on its debut weekend with $10.7m (-28%).
